Be Your Dreams, LLC assists high school students with college preparation so they can attend the college of their choice, pursue their desired career, and avoid student loans. We offer one-on-one and small group study sessions to high school students by offering services that focus on Improving GPA, Choosing A Major, Choosing A College, Improving OGT, ACT, or SAT scores, and Applying for Scholarships. If you would like personal assistance with preparing for the ACT or SAT please contact us with the following information:
Web: BeYourDreams.org
Email

Princeton Review
//act During each section of the practice test it is important to take it subject by subject, untimed, and have a notebook and pencil handy for notes on questions you get wrong.
For Example: take only the English test without time and in one sitting 1. Click your choice for the answer on each question
2. Write the number of the questions you don't get correct (i.e. Passage 3 Question 5) 3. Read and understand the pop up of the explanation of why it is incorrect and answer the question again.
4. When you get the question correct, take notes on the pop up that explains the correct answer. 5. Once you have completed the practice test on ACT.org for one subject (i.e. English), Do Not move on to the next subject 6. Keep the notes you took handy for after you determine your score. Scoring the Test
1. Score the test by determining the number of questions you got correct and understood on your first attempt at answering (just subtract the total number of questions you got wrong from the number of questions all together) 2. Then divide the number of questions you got correct by the total number of questions (For example: I got 57 questions right. There are 75 total questions. So 56 divided by 75 is 0.76. 3. Then multiply that number by 36. The answer you get is your score. The score should be between 1 & 36. (For example: 36 multiplied by 0.76 is 27.) 4. Now retake the same test according to the required time and repeat steps 5. If you do not reach the minimum score set by the exam administrators, thoroughly review and understand the notes you took on the incorrect answers first before you retake the test according to the required time. Contact Be Your Dreams for affordable sessions that walk you through the questions you got incorrect for better understanding Or Ask your High School teacher/Tutor of that particular subject of the test to walk you through answering the questions you got incorrect for better understanding //sat https://sat.collegeboard.org/practice
1. Write down each question that you do not understand or have trouble with as you take the practice test 2. After completing the test, go to Khan Academy to watch the video on those questions
3. Take notes of the explanations as you watch the video for each question 4. review and understand your notes for each question
5. Retake the print version of the practice test for best results
Princeton Review Princeton Review provides a copy of your score report for both the online and in person practice tests.
The score report consists of each question you got correct and incorrect Contact Be Your Dreams for affordable sessions that walk you through the questions you got incorrect for better understanding Or Ask your High School teacher/Tutor of that particular subject of the test to walk you through answering the questions you got incorrect for better understanding
Then retake the Princeton Review in person practice test for best results.
//act ACT

The ACT consists of Four required sections:
English
Math
Reading
Science
And an optional Writing section. The English test has 75 questions to complete in 45 minutes
You need a minimum score of 18 to be considered college ready. The Math test consists of 60 questions in 60 minutes
You need a minimum score of 22 to be college ready. The Reading test consists of 40 questions in 35 minutes
You need a minimum score of 22 to be considered college ready. The Science test consists of 40 questions to be completed in 35 minutes
You need a minimum score of 23 to be considered college ready. The Writing section consists of a 25 minute essay
You need a minimum score of 7 out of 12 to be considered college ready Only score English, Math, Reading, and Science for your composite score, the Writing section is scored separately. The highest possible score for the ACT is a 36.
The national average composite score for the ACT is a 21.
The total time for the ACT test is 3 hours and 45 minutes. For more information about what the ACT test consists of visit:
ACTStudent.org //sat SAT

Currently the SAT test consists of three sections:
Math
Critical Reading
Writing Math is made up of three separate sections equal to 70 minutes in time
It ranges from a score of 200 to 800.
The average Math score is 513. Critical Reading is made up of three separate sections equal to 45 minutes in time
It ranges from a score of 200 to 800.
The average Critical Reading score is 497. Writing skills is made up of one essay equal to 25 minutes in time; two grammar sections equal to 35 minutes, and an experimental section equal to 25 minutes Writing scores range from 200 to 800.
The average Writing Skills score is 487. The highest possible score for the SAT is a 2400.
The total time for the SAT test with the writing section is 3 hours and 45 minutes.
The total time for the SAT test without the writing section is 3 hours and 20 minutes. The SAT test will be redesigned for the graduating class of 2017. The new test dates are as follows:
March 2016
May 2016
June 2016 The Redesigned SAT taken by high school juniors in 2016 will consist of two sections:
Math and Evidence-Based Reading and Writing The Math consists of one 55 minute section with a calculator and one 20 minute section with no calculator.
It ranges from a score of 200 to 800. The Evidence-Based Reading and Writing portion will consist of one 65 minute reading section, one 35 minute Writing and Language section, and one Optional 50 minute essay.
It ranges from a score of 200 to 800. The highest possible score for the Redesigned SAT is a 1600.
The total time for the Redesigned SAT with the essay is 3 hours and 50 minutes.
The total time for the Redesigned SAT without the essay is 3 hours. For more information about what the SAT test consists of visit:
Test Masters
And
Princeton Review
